metadata.case_name: Bram Jansen - Cerebral Palsy and the Transition to Adulthood
metadata.prevention_cure_care_focus: Prevention of secondary complications, Cure through optimizing function, Care with participation focus throughout

patient_overview.name: Bram Jansen
patient_overview.setting: You encounter Bram across different settings as he grows: a children's rehabilitation center in Rotterdam, a mainstream secondary school, and eventually an adult rehabilitation service.
patient_overview.narrative_arc: Bram's story follows a young person with cerebral palsy from childhood through adolescence and into young adulthood. It illustrates the shifting priorities from motor development and preventing deformity in childhood, to participation and independence in adolescence, to self-determination and 'living with' CP in adulthood. The case highlights the critical transition from pediatric to adult services and the reality that CP is a lifelong condition requiring evolving support.

life_stage_1.title: Bram at 8 years old

presentation.referral: Regular review at children's rehabilitation center
presentation.setting: Outpatient pediatric physiotherapy, Rijndam Revalidatie Rotterdam
presentation.chief_complaint: Routine review, parents concerned about upcoming transition to 'grote school'

life_stage_1.patient_narrative: Bram Jansen is 8 years old and has spastic diplegic cerebral palsy (GMFCS Level II). He was born prematurely at 28 weeks and diagnosed with CP at 18 months. He attends a mainstream primary school (basisschool) in Rotterdam with some support. Bram walks independently but has a characteristic scissoring gait and has difficulty keeping up with his peers in the schoolyard. He uses a posterior walker for longer distances and has a wheelchair for family outings. Bram is a bright, cheerful boy who loves dinosaurs and playing Minecraft. His parents, Marco (38, IT consultant) and Sophie (36, part-time office manager), are actively involved in his care. They're anxious about his transition to secondary school (middelbare school) in a few years. 'Will he cope? Will he be bullied? Should we look at special education?' Bram himself seems less worried. When asked what he wants, he says, 'I want to play football with my friends, but they're too fast.'

q1.question: Would your therapeutic approach be focused more on prevention, cure, or care?
q1.teaching_answer: Prevention and Cure. Prevention of secondary musculoskeletal problems (contractures, hip displacement, crouch gait progression). 'Cure' through optimizing function - at age 8 with GMFCS II, there is still potential for motor gains. Participation is already important but will become central focus as he ages.

q2.question: Explain the significance of GMFCS Level II and what it predicts about Bram's future function.
q2.teaching_answer: GMFCS Level II: Walks independently, limitations outdoors/community, may use wheeled mobility for long distances, can use handrails for stairs. Prediction: GMFCS is stable after age 6 for most children. Bram will likely remain Level II but may function at the lower end without intervention. Risk: crouch gait can worsen in adolescence if not managed. Strength, flexibility, and fitness are modifiable factors.

q3.question: Bram's parents are worried about mainstream secondary school. How do you address this?
q3.teaching_answer: Approach: (1) Validate concerns - transition is challenging, (2) Focus on preparation rather than changing schools, (3) Discuss what he needs - physical access, fatigue management, peer relationships, (4) Many GMFCS II children succeed in mainstream with support, (5) Introduce gradual independence now (carrying own bag, managing breaks), (6) Connect with families who've navigated this, (7) Occupational therapy for school function. Inclusion is best supported by preparation, not avoidance.

q4.question: Bram says he wants to 'play football but they're too fast.' How do you use this goal therapeutically?
q4.teaching_answer: Using child's goals: (1) This is a COPM goal - meaningful to him, (2) Analyze the activity - football requires speed, agility, endurance, ball skills, (3) Modify the goal - maybe not competitive football but he could play goalkeeper, join CP football, or play adapted games, (4) Train component skills - endurance, speed, ball control, (5) Introduce alternatives - boccia, wheelchair basketball, frame football, (6) Social aspect is key - he wants to play WITH friends. Therapy goals should include participation in play, not just motor skills.

q5.question: What surveillance is needed for a child with GMFCS II CP?
q5.teaching_answer: CP surveillance (Dutch CPNET guidelines): (1) Hip surveillance - X-rays every 1-2 years until hip stable (risk of displacement), (2) Spine monitoring - scoliosis watch, (3) ROM monitoring - identify contracture early, (4) GMFM tracking - monitor for functional decline, (5) Nutrition and growth, (6) Communication and learning, (7) Vision and hearing. Early intervention prevents surgery/deterioration.

q6.question: Design a physiotherapy program for Bram at this stage.
q6.teaching_answer: PT program for 8-year-old GMFCS II: (1) Stretching - gastrocnemius, hamstrings, hip flexors (daily home program with parents), (2) Strengthening - functional lower limb strength, especially extensors (step-ups, sit-to-stand games), (3) Gait training - cueing for knee extension, reducing crouch, (4) Fitness - cycling (adapted if needed), swimming, active games, (5) Motor learning - bike riding if possible, ball skills, (6) AFO optimization - review with orthotist. Make it fun - games-based approach. Involve parents in home program.

reasoning_traps.description: Setting goals about 'normal gait' rather than participation
reasoning_traps.coaching_response: Your goals are about improving gait pattern and ROM. These are important, but what does Bram want? How do these impairment goals translate to playing with his friends?

reasoning_traps.description: Prescribing intensive therapy that leaves no time for play
reasoning_traps.coaching_response: You've prescribed daily stretching, 3x/week physio, and swimming. When does Bram just get to be a kid? How do we balance therapy with childhood?

reasoning_traps.description: Focusing on physical management without addressing parental anxiety
reasoning_traps.coaching_response: Marco and Sophie seem very anxious about secondary school. You've focused on exercises. Have you addressed their fears? Connected them with peer support?

life_stage_2.title: Bram at 14 years old

presentation.chief_complaint: Declining function, increasing fatigue, struggling at school, frustration

life_stage_2.patient_narrative: Bram is now 14 and in his second year of HAVO (secondary school). He's grown significantly - now tall and lanky after a recent growth spurt. His parents are concerned: his walking has deteriorated, he's more fatigued, and he's resistant to physiotherapy. 'He used to be so compliant, now he won't do his exercises or wear his AFOs.' Bram himself seems withdrawn. When you ask how school is going, he shrugs. Eventually he says, 'I'm sick of being different. I don't want people to see me with a walker. I just want to be normal.' He's stopped doing his stretches, refuses to wear AFOs at school, and has dropped out of CP football - 'too babyish.' He's interested in computers and gaming. Physically, he's developed more crouch in his gait, has lost some of the ROM he had at 8, and his endurance is reduced.

q1.question: Would your therapeutic approach be focused more on prevention, cure, or care?
q1.teaching_answer: Prevention of further deterioration (contracture, crouch progression). Cure of current deconditioning if possible. But critically, Care in terms of supporting adolescent development, identity, and participation. Cannot separate physical and psychosocial - both must be addressed.

q2.question: Why has Bram's function deteriorated? Explain the adolescent 'decline' in CP.
q2.teaching_answer: Multiple factors: (1) Growth spurt - muscles can't keep up with bone growth, relative muscle shortening, (2) Increased body weight with same muscle strength, (3) Decreased activity - social factors, avoidance, (4) Poor adherence to stretching/AFOs, (5) Possible progression of crouch gait pattern. This is common in GMFCS II-III - the 'teenage dip.' NOT inevitable - intervention can help, but requires engagement.

q3.question: Bram says 'I just want to be normal.' How do you respond?
q3.teaching_answer: This statement reflects identity struggle common in adolescents with disability. Response: (1) Validate - 'Of course you want that. Feeling different is hard.' (2) Explore - what does 'normal' mean to him? What specifically does he want? (3) Gently reframe - 'normal' is a myth; everyone has challenges, (4) Focus on function not appearance - what does he want to DO?, (5) Connect with positive disability identity - other successful adults with CP, role models, (6) May benefit from psychology/peer support. Don't lecture - listen first.

q4.question: Bram refuses his AFOs and walker at school. How do you approach this?
q4.teaching_answer: Adolescent autonomy approach: (1) This is his body - he has a right to make choices (with consequences), (2) Explore his reasoning - appearance? comfort? practical issues?, (3) Problem-solve together - more cosmetically acceptable options? Different equipment?, (4) Explain consequences without lecturing - 'If you don't stretch, this is what might happen,' (5) Negotiate - minimum necessary, (6) Accept he may choose function loss to gain social acceptance - that's his right. Transition to self-management means accepting his choices.

q5.question: Bram is interested in computers and gaming. How can you use this therapeutically?
q5.teaching_answer: Interest-led therapy: (1) Gaming can be exercise - active video games, VR, (2) Technology skills are valuable - could pursue IT career (cognitive ability intact), (3) Online communities - can connect with others without physical demands, (4) Use his interest to engage - therapy apps, exercise games, tracking technology, (5) Career counseling - many computer-based careers accessible with CP. Don't dismiss his interests as 'sedentary' - they're his identity and future.

q6.question: Should Bram have orthopedic surgery for his contractures?
q6.teaching_answer: Surgical considerations: (1) Current contractures (knee -15°, ankle -10°) may benefit from SEMLS (Single Event Multi-Level Surgery), (2) Goals: prevent further crouch, optimize function, (3) Requires significant post-op rehabilitation (6-12 months), (4) Bram must be willing - non-adherent adolescent + major surgery = poor outcome, (5) Discussion with orthopedic surgeon needed, (6) Timing matters - before further deterioration but when mature enough for commitment. Decision should involve Bram as primary decision-maker.

reasoning_traps.description: Insisting on AFO use and exercises despite adolescent resistance
reasoning_traps.coaching_response: You've emphasized that Bram must wear his AFOs and do his stretches. He's 14 and has refused for months. How's that approach working? What happens if you shift from compliance to collaboration?

reasoning_traps.description: Focusing on physical deterioration without addressing low mood and identity issues
reasoning_traps.coaching_response: Bram's WHO-5 is 32 and he seems withdrawn. You've focused on his ROM and exercise program. Is he in a state to engage with physical therapy? What needs to be addressed first?

reasoning_traps.description: Working with parents' concerns rather than Bram's goals
reasoning_traps.coaching_response: The parents want Bram to wear his AFOs and do his exercises. Bram wants to be normal. Whose goals are we treating? Who should set the direction of therapy at age 14?

life_stage_3.title: Bram at 18 years old

presentation.referral: Transition clinic - pediatric to adult services
presentation.chief_complaint: Transitioning to adult care, planning for higher education, questioning future

life_stage_3.patient_narrative: Bram is 18 and has just completed HAVO. He had orthopedic surgery at 15 (SEMLS - bilateral hamstring lengthening, gastrocnemius recession) and after a difficult year of rehabilitation, his function improved. He now uses a rollator full-time for community mobility and has accepted this. He's attending the transition clinic as he moves from pediatric to adult services. Bram has been accepted to HBO-ICT (university of applied sciences, computer science) in Rotterdam and will live in adapted student housing. He's nervous but excited. He has a small group of good friends and recently went on a first date. He's started following disability activists on Instagram and has become more vocal about accessibility. He asks you: 'What's going to happen to me as I get older? I read that people with CP have problems when they're adults. No one ever told me that.'

q1.question: Would your therapeutic approach be focused more on prevention, cure, or care?
q1.teaching_answer: Prevention of adult-onset complications (pain, fatigue, deterioration) and Care focused on participation, life role development, and self-management. Transition phase is critical - establishing adult healthcare habits now.

q2.question: Bram asks 'What's going to happen to me as I get older?' What is the evidence on aging with CP?
q2.teaching_answer: Aging with CP evidence: (1) Adults with CP often experience functional decline earlier than general population, (2) Pain is very common (>75%) and often undertreated, (3) Fatigue is a major issue, (4) Many ambulatory children become non-ambulatory adults (GMFCS can worsen), (5) Secondary conditions: osteoarthritis, osteoporosis, mental health issues, (6) Life expectancy is reduced especially for GMFCS IV-V. For Bram (GMFCS III): (1) Likely to maintain walking with aids if active, (2) Pain and fatigue are risks, (3) Fitness and strength maintenance are key. Honest information is important - he deserves to know and prepare.

q3.question: What are the key elements of a successful pediatric-to-adult transition for Bram?
q3.teaching_answer: Transition elements: (1) Medical - transfer to adult services with summary of history, ensure GP understands CP, (2) Self-management - shift from parent-managed to self-managed care, (3) Education/vocation - accommodations, accessibility, career planning, (4) Independent living - housing, transport, personal assistance, (5) Social/relational - friendships, dating, sexuality, (6) Financial - benefits, insurance, personal budget. Transition is a process not an event - should start years before transfer.

q4.question: Bram will live in student housing with PGB-funded support. Explain this Dutch system.
q4.teaching_answer: Dutch system: (1) WMO (Wet Maatschappelijke Ondersteuning) provides community support for disabilities, (2) PGB (Persoonsgebonden Budget) is personal budget to purchase care, (3) Bram can use PGB to hire care assistants for personal care, housework, (4) Wajong may provide income support if CP limits work capacity, (5) Student housing often has adapted units, (6) He'll need to coordinate his own care - different from parents doing it. Physiotherapy may continue under Zorgverzekeringswet (health insurance) with chronic indication.

q5.question: Bram is starting higher education in IT. What accommodations might he need and how do you support this?
q5.teaching_answer: Accommodations: (1) Physical accessibility - building access, adapted workstation, accessible toilet, (2) Exam accommodations - extra time, separate room, rest breaks, possible scribe if handwriting difficult, (3) Timetable - avoiding early mornings if fatigue is issue, breaks between classes, (4) Technology - speech-to-text, ergonomic keyboard, (5) Support - study advisor aware of needs, peer support. Physiotherapy role: (1) Provide documentation, (2) Advise on workstation ergonomics, (3) Fatigue management strategies, (4) Fitness program to maintain function through demanding studies.

q6.question: Design an adult maintenance physiotherapy plan for Bram.
q6.teaching_answer: Adult maintenance plan: (1) Frequency: periodic blocks rather than ongoing (e.g., 2x/year for 6-8 sessions), (2) Focus: fitness (gym program he can do independently), flexibility maintenance, pain prevention, (3) Self-management: he leads, physio advises, (4) Gym integration: liaise with fitness instructor, design accessible program, (5) Annual review: check ROM, function, any new issues, (6) As-needed access: flare-ups, new challenges. Shift to autonomy and episodic care rather than continuous therapy.

reasoning_traps.description: Treating 18-year-old like a child, involving parents as primary partners
reasoning_traps.coaching_response: You discussed Bram's care plan with his parents. He's 18 and moving out. Who is your primary partner now? How do you shift the therapeutic relationship?

reasoning_traps.description: Avoiding honest discussion about aging with CP
reasoning_traps.coaching_response: Bram asked what will happen as he ages. You gave a vague reassurance. He deserves honest information. What does the evidence say, and how do you share it appropriately?

reasoning_traps.description: Prescribing ongoing weekly therapy for a stable 18-year-old
reasoning_traps.coaching_response: You've prescribed weekly physiotherapy indefinitely. Is this the best model for a stable young adult starting university? What's the evidence for ongoing vs. episodic care in adult CP?

life_stage_4.title: Bram at 25 years old

presentation.chief_complaint: Increasing pain, worried about function, work challenges

life_stage_4.patient_narrative: Bram is now 25 and has graduated with his HBO-ICT degree. He works as a junior software developer at a tech company in Rotterdam. He lives independently in an accessible apartment with PGB-funded support for personal care and household tasks. He's in a relationship with Sanne, who he met through a disability community group. He's referred himself to physiotherapy because of increasing hip and back pain over the past year. He's also noticed he's more fatigued and feels like his walking is getting worse. He managed to avoid PT through university ('I was too busy and thought I'd outgrown it') but now is worried. 'I thought I had this figured out. I've got a job, I've got a girlfriend, I've got my own place. And now my body is letting me down. I'm 25, not 65.'

q1.question: Would your therapeutic approach be focused more on prevention, cure, or care?
q1.teaching_answer: Care with Prevention elements. Care focused on managing chronic condition, optimizing participation, and work sustainability. Prevention of further deterioration and secondary conditions (shoulder overuse, further hip damage). Some 'cure' may be possible for current pain with appropriate intervention.

q2.question: Bram says 'I'm 25, not 65.' Explain premature aging in cerebral palsy.
q2.teaching_answer: Premature aging in CP: (1) Musculoskeletal overload - abnormal forces over decades lead to early degeneration (hip OA common in CP), (2) Muscle imbalance and spasticity cause joint damage, (3) Reduced physical activity accelerates decline, (4) Pain is a major issue affecting 75%+ of adults with CP, (5) Many become more dependent in 30s-40s than they were in 20s. His experience is typical, not unusual. Reframe: not premature aging but 'living with CP across the lifespan' - predictable and manageable with the right support.

q3.question: Bram's hip pain is worsening. What investigation and management is indicated?
q3.teaching_answer: Hip assessment: (1) X-ray to assess for OA, hip morphology, (2) Referral to rehabilitation physician for comprehensive assessment, (3) Management options: physio for strengthening and pain management, medication (NSAIDs with caution), consider hip injection, surgery if severe OA. For CP-related hip OA: conservative first but may need arthroplasty earlier than general population. Important: don't dismiss pain as 'just CP' - investigate properly.

q4.question: Bram is experiencing upper limb overuse from wheelchair propulsion and typing. How do you address this?
q4.teaching_answer: Upper limb preservation is critical for wheelchair users: (1) Assess wheelchair setup - may need power assist or switch to power wheelchair for longer distances, (2) Ergonomic workstation - keyboard, mouse, positioning, (3) Upper limb strengthening and stretching program, (4) Activity modification - reduce unnecessary transfers, (5) Consider voice-to-text for some typing, (6) Regular monitoring - upper limbs are his lifeline for independence. Upper limb pain is the beginning of a serious problem - address early.

q5.question: Bram works full-time and is worried about sustainability. What are his options?
q5.teaching_answer: Work sustainability options: (1) Reasonable accommodations under Dutch employment law - modified hours, remote work, breaks, (2) Reduced hours (he's already at 32), (3) Energy management training - pacing across day/week, (4) Workplace assessment by arbeidsdeskundige, (5) Wajong or WIA for partial income support if needed, (6) Career counseling - is current role sustainable long-term? IT has many less physical options. Goal is sustainable career, not burning out by 30.

q6.question: Bram fell through the gap between pediatric and adult services for 7 years. How should adult CP healthcare be structured?
q6.teaching_answer: Adult CP healthcare model (what should exist): (1) Regular review by rehabilitation physician who knows CP (annually or as needed), (2) Access to physiotherapy for episodic intervention and maintenance, (3) Access to other specialists (orthopedics, pain, psychology) as needed, (4) Case manager or care coordinator for complex needs, (5) Transition from pediatric should include warm handoff, (6) GP education about CP in adults. Reality: many adults with CP are lost to follow-up and present only when problems develop. Advocacy for better adult CP services is needed.

reasoning_traps.trap: Blaming the patient for the gap
reasoning_traps.description: Focusing on him avoiding physio for 7 years rather than system failures
reasoning_traps.coaching_response: You mentioned that Bram should have continued with physio through university. Was that service available and accessible? What does the system do to keep adults with CP in care?

reasoning_traps.description: Telling him functional decline is 'just what happens with CP'
reasoning_traps.coaching_response: You've told Bram that some decline is expected. Is all of his current decline inevitable? His hip pain may be treatable. His fitness is modifiable. What can we actually change?

reasoning_traps.description: Focusing only on physical symptoms without considering occupational factors
reasoning_traps.coaching_response: You've addressed his hip pain and prescribed exercises. But he's worried about his job. How does his work contribute to his symptoms? Is his current work pattern sustainable? Who else should be involved?

longitudinal_reflection.trajectory_summary: Bram's journey from childhood through young adulthood illustrates that cerebral palsy is a lifelong condition requiring evolving support. Key transitions - from childhood to adolescence, pediatric to adult services, and school to work - each brought new challenges. The focus shifted from motor development and preventing deformity in childhood, to identity and participation in adolescence, to self-determination and sustainable function in adulthood. The gap in adult services represents a systemic failure that many adults with CP experience.
key_lessons: GMFCS provides useful but not absolute prediction - level can worsen without intervention
Adolescence is a vulnerable period - physical changes plus identity development plus non-adherence
Transition to adult services is a critical period requiring careful planning
Adults with CP experience premature musculoskeletal aging, pain, and fatigue
Upper limb preservation is critical for wheelchair users
Work sustainability requires proactive accommodation and sometimes reduced expectations
Adult CP healthcare is poorly developed - many fall through the gaps
Disability identity development is as important as physical rehabilitation
